+1

Tests give me a place to put breakpoints, so I can see what's
going on when something fails.

Fine-grained tests give me more places to put the breakpoints,
with smaller chunks of code surrounded by tests.

Example:
   A calls B1, B2, and B3.
   Each Bn calls C1, C2, C3.

That's 13 function points in all for this trivially stupid
example.

With tests that pass C1, C2, and C3, a bug in B1 has to be
in the B1 code itself. Similarly, once B1, B2, and B3 have
passed, a failure in A has to be in the A code, rather than
somewhere under A in the calling hierarchy.

When a test of A fails, the input conditions for the failure
are given. The first breakpoint I set is usually at the 
assertion that failed, to see what the results were and to
examine values.

Often, that information is sufficient to reveal the bug.
Sometimes, I need to examine A's state, so I rerun
the test and visit A to find out. I now *should* have
enough information to see the problem -- but only because 
the bug is necessarily limited to A, and does not lie any 
lower in the calling hierarchy.

Anything beyond a cursory examination of the object's
state, however, is a significant indicator.

If the method is too complex, or its underlying parts are 
insufficiently tested, or both, I find myself tracing the
code to follow the logic -- and that symptom pretty clearly
indicates that the code needs more refactoring and/or more
testing.


Erik Hanson wrote:
> 
> <steven.hale@...> wrote:
> > Does junit make debuggers obsolete? Are there situations where junit in
> > partnership with logging isn't sufficient?
> 
> In my experience, unit testing makes logging obsolete and makes the debugger
> much more powerful.
> 
> When I have a problem that I can't figure out by looking at the code, I just
> set a breakpoint in a test, run the test, and examine the variables. Logging
> forces you to guess ahead of time what you're going to want to see, but
> debugging lets you choose what you w ant to see at runtime.
> 
> I find that much easier than putting in logging statements, wading through
> logging output, and then removing the logging statements. It also saves me
> from reading the output from the logging statements that others on the team
> have accidentally left in.
>
